page.title: 19MONUMENTS OF THE PAST
page.content: The Cross situated on the roadside just outside Bisley on the way to Stroud originally marked the Parish boundary between the Manors of Bisley and Lypiatt. It was known as the Lord's Stone and mentioned as early as 1654. On one side is the figure of a saint with uplifted arms, and on the other the Virgin. Both are beneath arches. A later "PB" as been added to show the limit of the Parish boundary. On the roads to both Bourne's Green and Througham there are the remains of neolithic barrows. A thirteenth century cross stands at the west end of Bisley churchyard. It is twelve feet high. It is nicknamed "The Bone House". Many of the names locally are a record of past times: George Street, Dr Crouch's Road, Bearsfield, Priest Hollow, Cricketty Mill and the Chantry.
